Dictionary.Name: The Free On-line Dictionary of Computing (27 SEP 03)

Definition.WordDefinition:
era
Synonym {epoch}. Webster's Unabridged makes these words almost synonymous, but "era" usually connotes a span of time rather than a point in time.

Dictionary.Name: The Free On-line Dictionary of Computing (27 SEP 03)
The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Era \E"ra\, n.; pl. {Eras}. [LL. aera an era, in earlier usage, the items of an account, counters, pl. of aes, aeris, brass, money. See {Ore}.] 1. A fixed point of time, usually an epoch, from which a series of years is reckoned. [1913 Webster]
The foundation of Solomon's temple is conjectured by Ideler to have been an era. --R. S. Poole. [1913 Webster]
2. A period of time reckoned from some particular date or epoch; a succession of years dating from some important event; as, the era of Alexander; the era of Christ, or the Christian era (see under {Christian}). [1913 Webster]
The first century of our era. --M. Arnold. [1913 Webster]
3. A period of time in which a new order of things prevails; a signal stage of history; an epoch. [1913 Webster]
Painting may truly be said to have opened the new era of culture. --J. A. Symonds.
Syn: Epoch; time; date; period; age; dispensation. See {Epoch}. [1913 Webster]

era n. Syn. {epoch}. Webster's Unabridged makes these words almost synonymous, but `era' more often connotes a span of time rather than a point in time, whereas the reverse is true for {epoch}. The {epoch} usage is recommended.

era n 1: a period marked by distinctive character or reckoned from a fixed point or event [syn: {epoch}] 2: a major division of geological time; an era is usually divided into two or more periods [syn: {geological era}]
